poem:
### The Mislaid Edge

In her stitched silence,  
a phantom blade whispered,  
nicked thought from flesh.  
Unseen, the razor's ghost  
lodged in a quiet fold,  
a steely confession to  
the unseen X-ray.  
Second cut, a surgeon's  
redemption—skin folds  
back around absence,  
mending the unplanned,  
scarred verses stitched  
along her ivory page.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Woman suing NHS trust after blade broke off during surgery and lodged itself in her body Jane Harvey* suffered horrendous physical and mental consequences when, during an abdominal hysterectomy in October 2023, the tip of one of the surgeon’s blades broke off and lodged inside her without any of the operating theatre staff noticing or an X-ray spotting it. As a result the 44-year-old had to undergo further surgery to remove the mislaid blade part". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
